Articles.Content: Oh damn. I really was hoping for a satellite bay.

Oh damn. I really was hoping for a satellite bay.

its coming once it can be animated. All the necessary work has already been done. Just check nova\'s page on the orbiter forum.
Quickly made an ET for Vanguard, then grabbed some SRBs from an Orbiter project of mine:

that would take me several days to model

that et would

looks awesome
Woaaaaaaaaah.

Quickly made an ET for Vanguard, then grabbed some SRBs from an Orbiter project of mine:

-snip snip-

I got you covered with the shuttle Nova.
Those looks great. I know you made it to have the same proportions as the space shuttle but are you sure it has enough mass to get into orbit? Looks kinds small.

Those looks great. I know you made it to have the same proportions as the space shuttle but are you sure it has enough mass to get into orbit? Looks kinds small.

I don\'t think mass has anything to do with being able to orbit. I don\'t see why it wouldn\'t be able to orbit: especially if it could get above the atmosphere, and go at orbital velocity.

I don\'t think mass has anything to do with being able to orbit. I don\'t see why it wouldn\'t be able to orbit: especially if it could get above the atmosphere, and go at orbital velocity.

Fuel mass. It needs enough energy to get out of the atmosphere and reach orbital velocity. Although the total mass of the craft influences the total energy required so its a carefully balanced problem.
In reality yes. In KSP it\'s magic and dictated only by the part developer. It can have the mass of a blood cell and the fuel of all the LH2/LOX in the universe for all the game cares.

In reality yes. In KSP it\'s magic and dictated only by the part developer. It can have the mass of a blood cell and the fuel of all the LH2/LOX in the universe for all the game cares.

But nova likes his stuff to be balanced.

Well, in real life the SRBs provide the vast majority of thrust to launch the Shuttle, so, we could just assume Nova has an ATK-esque design, and the LFE\'s can cover the remaining velocity gap in LKO.

Yeah. those SRB... lovely things they are.

'Together they provided about 83% of liftoff thrust for the Space Shuttle. They were located on either side of the rusty or orange-colored external propellant tank. Each SRB produced 80% more liftoff thrust than one F-1 engine, the most powerful single-chamber liquid-fueled rocket engine ever flown ' wikipedia

Well, they\'re the product of one of the largest conglomerates the world has ever seen (Honeywell, ATK formed from them). They produce pretty much every solid rocket engine for U.S. missile systems, and have enough weight to throw around that they insured their SRBs would co-power the next foreseeable generations of NASA\'s manned space vehicles.

Made a little cubesat for Probodobodyne.

(New silisko edition is going to take a LONG time to finish, so don\'t hold your breath yet)
How big is it?
I want to launch 12 dozen of those. At once.
How big is it?
10*10*10cm?

How big is it?

Edit: It has occurred to me that this is insanely small.
I laughed at that more than I should have. Why so small?

I laughed at that more than I should have. Why so small?

I upped the size a tad, so it should be better now.

Edit: I am encountering a problem
lol\'d. What exactly is the cubesat for? I understand it\'s probably not functional, but what\'s it\'s intended function?

lol\'d. What exactly is the cubesat for? I understand it\'s probably not functional, but what\'s it\'s intended function?

a satellite that is a cube. Right now satellites do not function in any way. they are just payloads for missions. Once we have persistence, they could become objects to visit in orbit.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CubeSat

Wikipedia is your friend!
